Hmm, okay, I think I’d probably just type in my expenses myself at first. Connecting it to the bank sounds a bit complicated and maybe risky for me. Could we maybe add that later if I get more comfortable? For the alerts, I mostly just want something that tells me when I’m spending too much on stuff I don’t really need — like eating out or impulse shopping. Maybe it could pop up on my phone as a notification? I don’t think I need emails or SMS. I like the idea of tips, but nothing too fancy. Just simple advice, like “you could save more if you cut back on coffee” — things I can actually understand. For the app itself, I think a phone app would be easiest since I always have my phone with me. Do you think it’s better to start with just Android first, or try both Android and iPhone? As for extras, I wouldn’t mind seeing some reports with charts, but I don’t want it to feel too complicated. Maybe just a simple graph showing where my money went each month. Does that make sense, or do you think I’m starting off too simple?

{"type": "ideation", "message": "Hmm, okay, I think I\u2019d probably just type in my expenses myself at first. Connecting it to the bank sounds a bit complicated and maybe risky for me. Could we maybe add that later if I get more comfortable? For the alerts, I mostly just want something that tells me when I\u2019m spending too much on stuff I don\u2019t really need \u2014 like eating out or impulse shopping. Maybe it could pop up on my phone as a notification? I don\u2019t think I need emails or SMS. I like the idea of tips, but nothing too fancy. Just simple advice, like \u201cyou could save more if you cut back on coffee\u201d \u2014 things I can actually understand. For the app itself, I think a phone app would be easiest since I always have my phone with me. Do you think it\u2019s better to start with just Android first, or try both Android and iPhone? As for extras, I wouldn\u2019t mind seeing some reports with charts, but I don\u2019t want it to feel too complicated. Maybe just a simple graph showing where my money went each month. Does that make sense, or do you think I\u2019m starting off too simple?"}

Alright, I get you. For categories, I think the basics are enough for me — food, rent, transport, and then maybe “fun stuff” for things like movies or impulse buys. I don’t think I need too many fancy categories right now. For budgets, I’m thinking just a fixed amount per month. Like “I don’t want to spend more than this on food” — something easy I can keep track of.

{"type": "ideation", "message": "Alright, I get you. For categories, I think the basics are enough for me \u2014 food, rent, transport, and then maybe \u201cfun stuff\u201d for things like movies or impulse buys. I don\u2019t think I need too many fancy categories right now. For budgets, I\u2019m thinking just a fixed amount per month. Like \u201cI don\u2019t want to spend more than this on food\u201d \u2014 something easy I can keep track of."}

On overspending, maybe the app could warn me when I’m close, like if I hit 80% of the budget, and then again if I go over. That way I get an early heads-up. About storing the data… I don’t know, maybe a year? I don’t want to lose track of my spending too quickly, but I also don’t want the app to feel heavy or slow. I mostly use Android, so I think we can start there. Would it be easier to build for Android first and then later add iPhone? For reports, I think monthly is enough. Maybe just a simple bar graph or pie chart so I can see where most of my money went. Nothing too complicated.android and very simple, Q-pending is the name
